00017 namespace GeographicLib {

00019   using namespace std;
00020 
00021   Geocentric::Geocentric(real a, real r)
00022     : _a(a)
00023     , _r(r)
00024     , _f(_r != 0 ? 1 / _r : 0)
00025     , _e2(_f * (2 - _f))
00026     , _e2m(sq(1 - _f))          // 1 - _e2
00027       // Constants with the x suffix are for use by Reverse and support prolate
00028       // spheroids by interchanging the roles of a and b.
00029     , _ax(_f >= 0 ? _a : _a * (1 - _f))
00030     , _e2x(_f >= 0 ? _e2 : - _e2/(1 - _e2))
00031     , _e4x(sq(_e2x))
00032     , _e2mx(_f >= 0 ? _e2m : 1/_e2m)
00033     , _maxrad(2 * _ax / numeric_limits<real>::epsilon())
00034   {
00035     if (!(_a > 0))
00036       throw GeographicErr("Major radius is not positive");
00037   }
00038 
00039   const Geocentric Geocentric::WGS84(Constants::WGS84_a(),
00040                                      Constants::WGS84_r());
00041 
00042   void Geocentric::Forward(real lat, real lon, real h,
00043                            real& x, real& y, real& z) const throw() {
00044     lon = lon >= 180 ? lon - 360 : lon < -180 ? lon + 360 : lon;
00045     real
00046       phi = lat * Constants::degree(),
00047       lam = lon * Constants::degree(),
00048       sphi = sin(phi),
00049       cphi = abs(lat) == 90 ? 0 : cos(phi),
00050       n = _a/sqrt(1 - _e2 * sq(sphi));
00051     z = ( _e2m * n + h) * sphi;
00052     x = (n + h) * cphi;
00053     y = x * (lon == -180 ? 0 : sin(lam));
00054     x *= (abs(lon) == 90 ? 0 : cos(lam));
00055   }
00056 
00057   void Geocentric::Reverse(real x, real y, real z,
00058                            real& lat, real& lon, real& h) const throw() {
00059     real R = Math::hypot(x, y);
00060     h = Math::hypot(R, z);      // Distance to center of earth
00061     real phi;
00062     if (h > _maxrad)
00063       // We really far away (> 12 million light years); treat the earth as a
00064       // point and h, above, is an acceptable approximation to the height.
00065       // This avoids overflow, e.g., in the computation of disc below.  It's
00066       // possible that h has overflowed to inf; but that's OK.
00067       //
00068       // Treat the case x, y finite, but R overflows to +inf by scaling by 2.
00069       phi = atan2(z/2, Math::hypot(x/2, y/2));
00070     else if (_e4x == 0) {
00071       // Treat the spherical case.  Dealing with underflow in the general case
00072       // with _e2 = 0 is difficult.  Origin maps to N pole same as an
00073       // ellipsoid.
00074       phi = atan2(h != 0 ? z : real(1), R);
00075       h -= _ax;
00076     } else {
00077       // Treat prolate spheroids by swapping R and z here and by switching
00078       // the arguments to phi = atan2(...) at the end.
00079       if (_f < 0) swap(R, z);
00080       real
00081         p = sq(R / _ax),
00082         q = _e2mx * sq(z / _ax),
00083         r = (p + q - _e4x) / 6;
00084       if ( !(_e4x * q == 0 && r <= 0) ) {
00085         real
00086           // Avoid possible division by zero when r = 0 by multiplying
00087           // equations for s and t by r^3 and r, resp.
00088           S = _e4x * p * q / 4, // S = r^3 * s
00089           r2 = sq(r),
00090           r3 = r * r2,
00091           disc =  S * (2 * r3 + S);
00092         real u = r;
00093         if (disc >= 0) {
00094           real T3 = r3 + S;
00095           // Pick the sign on the sqrt to maximize abs(T3).  This minimizes
00096           // loss of precision due to cancellation.  The result is unchanged
00097           // because of the way the T is used in definition of u.
00098           T3 += T3 < 0 ? -sqrt(disc) : sqrt(disc); // T3 = (r * t)^3
00099           // N.B. cbrt always returns the real root.  cbrt(-8) = -2.
00100           real T = Math::cbrt(T3); // T = r * t
00101           // T can be zero; but then r2 / T -> 0.
00102           u += T + (T != 0 ? r2 / T : 0);
00103         } else {
00104           // T is complex, but the way u is defined the result is real.
00105           real ang = atan2(sqrt(-disc), r3 + S);
00106           // There are three possible real solutions for u depending on the
00107           // multiple of 2*pi here.  We choose multiplier = 1 which leads to a
00108           // jump in the solution across the line 2 + s = 0; but this
00109           // nevertheless leads to a continuous (and accurate) solution for k.
00110           // Other choices of the multiplier lead to poorly conditioned
00111           // solutions near s = 0 (i.e., near p = 0 or q = 0).
00112           u += 2 * abs(r) * cos((2 * Constants::pi() + ang) / real(3));
00113         }
00114         real
00115           v = sqrt(sq(u) + _e4x * q), // guaranteed positive
00116           // Avoid loss of accuracy when u < 0.  Underflow doesn't occur in
00117           // e4 * q / (v - u) because u ~ e^4 when q is small and u < 0.
00118           uv = u < 0 ? _e4x * q / (v - u) : u + v, // u+v, guaranteed positive
00119           // Need to guard against w going negative due to roundoff in uv - q.
00120           w = max(real(0), _e2x * (uv - q) / (2 * v)),
00121           // Rearrange expression for k to avoid loss of accuracy due to
00122           // subtraction.  Division by 0 not possible because uv > 0, w >= 0.
00123           k = uv / (sqrt(uv + sq(w)) + w), // guaranteed positive
00124           d = k * R / (k + _e2x);
00125         // Probably atan2 returns the result for phi more accurately than the
00126         // half-angle formula that Vermeille uses.  It's certainly simpler.
00127         phi = _f >= 0 ? atan2(z, d) : atan2(d, z);
00128         h = (k + _e2x - 1) * Math::hypot(d, z) / k;
00129       } else {                  // e4 * q == 0 && r <= 0
00130         // Very near equatorial plane with R <= a * e^2.  This leads to k = 0
00131         // using the general formula and division by 0 in formula for h.  So
00132         // handle this case directly.  The condition e4 * q == 0 implies abs(z)
00133         // < 1.e-145 for WGS84 so it's OK to treat these points as though z =
00134         // 0.  (But we do take care that the sign of phi matches the sign of
00135         // z.)
00136         phi = _f >= 0 ?
00137           atan2(sqrt( -6 * r), sqrt(p * _e2mx)) :
00138           atan2(sqrt(p * _e2mx), sqrt( -6 * r));
00139         if (z < 0) phi = -phi;  // for tiny negative z (not for prolate)
00140         h = - _a * (_f >= 0 ? _e2m : real(1)) / sqrt(1 - _e2 * sq(sin(phi)));
00141       }
00142     }
00143     lat = phi / Constants::degree();
00144     // Negative signs return lon in [-180, 180).  Assume atan2(0,0) = 0.
00145     lon = -atan2(-y, x) / Constants::degree();
00146   }
